alternateName: Explore a world of travel with Expedia

distribution.name: archive.zip
distribution.description: Archive containing all the contents of the Expedia Hotel dataset

distribution.name: test.csv
distribution.description:
The **Dataset** is related to tourism sector and is multivariate, dependent on time series. The main objective here is to check and observe the hotel prices from the data set of expedia hotel search. I have implemented different models here to check the prices hikes and lows.

[**Reference**](https://www.kaggle.com/c/expedia-personalized-sort/data)

**test.csv** - this contains data for both the public leaderboard and the final evaluation, which is randomly split between the two sets)

✏️ Note: test.csv does not contain the following columns: position, click_bool, gross_bookings_usd, nor booking_bool

distribution.name: train.csv
distribution.description:
The **Dataset** is related to tourism sector and is multivariate, dependent on time series. The main objective here is to check and observe the hotel prices from the data set of expedia hotel search. I have implemented different models here to check the prices hikes and lows.

[**Reference**](https://www.kaggle.com/c/expedia-personalized-sort/data)

**train.csv** - the training set

field.name: srch_id
field.description: The ID of the search

field.name: date_time
field.description: Date and time of the search

field.name: site_id
field.description: ID of the Expedia point of sale (i.e. Expedia.com, Expedia.co.uk, Expedia.co.jp, ..)

field.name: visitor_location_country_id
field.description: The ID of the country the customer is located

field.name: visitor_hist_starrating
field.description: The mean star rating of hotels the customer has previously purchased; null signifies there is no purchase history on the customer

field.name: visitor_hist_adr_usd
field.description: The mean price per night (in US$) of the hotels the customer has previously purchased; null signifies there is no purchase history on the customer

field.name: prop_country_id
field.description: The ID of the country the hotel is located in

field.name: prop_id
field.description: The ID of the hotel

field.name: prop_starrating
field.description: The star rating of the hotel, from 1 to 5, in increments of 1.  A 0 indicates the property has no stars, the star rating is not known or cannot be publicized.

field.name: prop_review_score
field.description: The mean customer review score for the hotel on a scale out of 5, rounded to 0.5 increments. A 0 means there have been no reviews, null that the information is not available.

field.name: prop_brand_bool
field.description: +1 if the hotel is part of a major hotel chain; 0 if it is an independent hotel

field.name: prop_location_score1
field.description: A (first) score outlining the desirability of a hotel’s location

field.name: prop_location_score2
field.description: A (second) score outlining the desirability of the hotel’s location

field.name: prop_log_historical_price
field.description: The logarithm of the mean price of the hotel over the last trading period. A 0 will occur if the hotel was not sold in that period.

field.name: price_usd
field.description: Displayed price of the hotel for the given search.  Note that different countries have different conventions regarding displaying taxes and fees and the value may be per night or for the whole stay

field.name: promotion_flag
field.description: +1 if the hotel had a sale price promotion specifically displayed

field.name: srch_destination_id
field.description: search destination id

field.name: srch_length_of_stay
field.description: Number of nights stay that was searched

field.name: srch_booking_window
field.description: Number of days in the future the hotel stay started from the search date

field.name: srch_adults_count
field.description: The number of adults specified in the hotel room

field.name: srch_children_count
field.description: The number of (extra occupancy) children specified in the hotel room

field.name: srch_room_count
field.description: Number of hotel rooms specified in the search

field.name: srch_saturday_night_bool
field.description: +1 if the stay includes a Saturday night, starts from Thursday with a length of stay is less than or equal to 4 nights (i.e. weekend); otherwise 0

field.name: srch_query_affinity_score
field.description: The log of the probability a hotel will be clicked on in Internet searches (hence the values are negative)  A null signifies there are no data (i.e. hotel did not register in any searches)

field.name: orig_destination_distance
field.description: Physical distance between the hotel and the customer at the time of search. A null means the distance could not be calculated.

field.name: random_bool
field.description: +1 when the displayed sort was random, 0 when the normal sort order was displayed

field.name: comp1_rate
field.description: +1 if Expedia has a lower price than competitor 1 for the hotel; 0 if the same; -1 if Expedia’s price is higher than competitor 1; null signifies there is no competitive data

field.name: comp1_inv
field.description: +1 if competitor 1 does not have availability in the hotel; 0 if both Expedia and competitor 1 have availability; null signifies there is no competitive data

field.name: comp1_rate_percent_diff
field.description: The absolute percentage difference (if one exists) between Expedia and competitor 1’s price (Expedia’s price the denominator); null signifies there is no competitive data

field.name: comp2_inv
field.description: (same, for competitor 2 through 8)

The **Dataset** is related to tourism sector and is multivariate, dependent on time series. The main objective here is to check and observe the hotel prices from the data set of expedia hotel search. I have implemented different models here to check the prices hikes and lows.

[**Reference**](https://www.kaggle.com/c/expedia-personalized-sort/data)

field.description: Physical distance between the hotel and the customer at the time of search. A null means the distance could not be calculated.

field.name: random_bool
field.description: +1 when the displayed sort was random, 0 when the normal sort order was displayed

field.description: +1 if Expedia has a lower price than competitor 1 for the hotel; 0 if the same; -1 if Expedia’s price is higher than competitor 1; null signifies there is no competitive data

field.description: +1 if competitor 1 does not have availability in the hotel; 0 if both Expedia and competitor 1 have availability; null signifies there is no competitive data

field.name: comp1_rate_percent_diff
field.description: The absolute percentage difference (if one exists) between Expedia and competitor 1’s price (Expedia’s price the denominator); null signifies there is no competitive data

recordSet.name: train.csv
recordSet.description:
The **Dataset** is related to tourism sector and is multivariate, dependent on time series. The main objective here is to check and observe the hotel prices from the data set of expedia hotel search. I have implemented different models here to check the prices hikes and lows.

[**Reference**](https://www.kaggle.com/c/expedia-personalized-sort/data)

**train.csv** - the training set

keywords: subject > people and society > business > travel
subject > science and technology > computer science > artificial intelligence
name: Expedia Hotel
description: Expedia Group, Inc. is an American online travel shopping company for consumer and small business travel. 👉🏻 Expedia is the world’s largest online travel agency (OTA) and powers search results for millions of travel shoppers every day. In this competitive market matching users to hotel inventory is very important since users easily jump from website to website. As such, having the best ranking of hotels (“sort”) for specific users with the best integration of price competitiveness gives an OTA the best chance of winning the sale. 👉🏻 Expedia has provided a dataset that includes shopping and purchase data and information on price competitiveness. The data are organized around a set of “search result impressions”, or the ordered list of hotels that the user sees after they search for a hotel on the Expedia website. In addition to impressions from the existing algorithm, the data contain impressions where the hotels were randomly sorted, to avoid the position bias of the existing algorithm. The user response is provided as a click on a hotel or/and a purchase of a hotel room. Appended to impressions are the following: 1) Hotel characteristics 2) Location attractiveness of hotels 3) User’s aggregate purchase history 4) Competitive OTA information
